manuscript.notes: The date shows a peculiarity. Although it seems to be 1008 YE, it could be also 1018 YE. Number X in Pahlavi script appears after number VIII. This is not at all expected and there is no parallel, but we may not discard the possibility that the date is 1018 YE and not 1008 YE. Both would match with the age of the scribe. The manuscript is dedicated to Xusrō Esfandyār (†).

scribes.scribe: Mihrābān Kayxusrō Mihrābān Sfandyād Mihrābān Marzbān Wahrām Šahryār Rōzweh Šāhburzēn Šāhmard

manuscript.notes: The copies of ms. 4600 that include the colophons show all a further colophon after the one by Mihrābān Kayxōsrō written in Navsāri in 1323. The last colophon is written as well in Navsāri and by a certain Mihrābān, likely the proper Mihrābān Kayxōsrō. Thus, it is uncertain whether the extant copy is Mihrābān's manuscript of 1323 or 1363. Notice that no certain copy of the 1st manuscript copied by Mihrābān Kayxōssō is known to uis. As far as we can judge, all copies go back to the 2nd copy of 1363. It seems as the second copy substituted the 1st one or the 1st onelost after the production of the second one. Accordingly, the possibility that the ms. 4600, hosted in the British Library, is the second copy appears as more liklely than the alternative one. (AC)
